newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU to clear Motorola's satellite phones system.
newsitem.headline: EU to clear Motorola's satellite phones system.

text.p: The European Commission said on Wednesday it planned to clear the Motorola-led Iridium satellite communications system but said it wanted to hear from other interested parties before making a final decision.

The Iridium system was conceived in 1987 to provide voice, paging and basic data services via portable phones and other equipment using satellites, the Commission said in a statement published in the European Union's Official Journal.
The system is due to start operations by October 1, 1998.

The EU's competition watchdog estimates the market for satellite-based communications using hand-held terminals will generate revenues of 10 to 20 billion European currency units during the next decade.
But due to the limited number of frequencies and the heavy cost involved in launching and operating satellites the number of players is deemed to be reduced and competition to be fierce.

The Commission started a probe in May 1995 into the Iridium project, therefore forcing Motorola, a U.S. provider of wireless communications and electronic equipment, to submit the project for formal clearance.

The EU involvement arises from the fact that the project is by nature a global one. It also involves European partners Vebacom of Germany and Italy's Stet who have respectively 10 percent and 3.8 percent in it.
The Commission is also examining a rival satellite-personal comunications systems, or S-PCS, Globalstar. It has already cleared a system run by Inmarsat-P.
In signalling its intention to clear Iridium, the EU executive took into consideration that Inmarsat-P wil be operational by the end of the year 2000.
Globalstar will also start offering services "around 1999 to 2000 in the United States and globally around five years later", it said.

Globalstar is a consortium led by the Loral Corporation, a leading U.S. defence electronics company. Inmarsat-P is being developed by the International Maritime Satellite Organisation (Inmarsat) which includes European telecommunications companies Telefonica of Spain, Swiss Telecom and Telecom Finland.
